speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: SCENE III. The Council-Chamber.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Enter Chancellor; places himself at the upper end  of the table on the left hand; a seat being left  void above him, as for CRANMER's seat. SUFFOLK,  NORFOLK, SURREY, Chamberlain, GARDINER, seat  themselves in order on each side. CROMWELL at lower end, as secretary. Keeper at the door

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Speak to the business, master-secretary:

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Why are we met in council?

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Please your honours,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: The chief cause concerns his grace of Canterbury.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Has he had knowledge of it?

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Who waits there?

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: Without, my noble lords?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: My lord archbishop;

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: And has done half an hour, to know your pleasures.

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Let him come in.

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: Your grace may enter now.

speaker: Keeper
text_entry: CRANMER enters and approaches the council-table

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: My good lord archbishop, I'm very sorry

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: To sit here at this present, and behold

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: That chair stand empty: but we all are men,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: In our own natures frail, and capable

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Of our flesh; few are angels: out of which frailty

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: And want of wisdom, you, that best should teach us,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Have misdemean'd yourself, and not a little,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Toward the king first, then his laws, in filling

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: The whole realm, by your teaching and your chaplains,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: For so we are inform'd, with new opinions,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Divers and dangerous; which are heresies,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: And, not reform'd, may prove pernicious.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Which reformation must be sudden too,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: My noble lords; for those that tame wild horses

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Pace 'em not in their hands to make 'em gentle,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: But stop their mouths with stubborn bits, and spur 'em,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Till they obey the manage. If we suffer,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Out of our easiness and childish pity

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: To one man's honour, this contagious sickness,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Farewell all physic: and what follows then?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Commotions, uproars, with a general taint

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Of the whole state: as, of late days, our neighbours,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: The upper Germany, can dearly witness,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Yet freshly pitied in our memories.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: My good lords, hitherto, in all the progress

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Both of my life and office, I have labour'd,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And with no little study, that my teaching

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And the strong course of my authority

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Might go one way, and safely; and the end

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Was ever, to do well: nor is there living,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: I speak it with a single heart, my lords,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: A man that more detests, more stirs against,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Both in his private conscience and his place,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Defacers of a public peace, than I do.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Pray heaven, the king may never find a heart

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: With less allegiance in it! Men that make

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Envy and crooked malice nourishment

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Dare bite the best. I do beseech your lordships,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: That, in this case of justice, my accusers,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Be what they will, may stand forth face to face,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And freely urge against me.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: Nay, my lord,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: That cannot be: you are a counsellor,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: And, by that virtue, no man dare accuse you.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: My lord, because we have business of more moment,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: We will be short with you. 'Tis his highness' pleasure,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: And our consent, for better trial of you,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: From hence you be committed to the Tower;

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Where, being but a private man again,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: You shall know many dare accuse you boldly,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: More than, I fear, you are provided for.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Ah, my good Lord of Winchester, I thank you;

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: You are always my good friend; if your will pass,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: I shall both find your lordship judge and juror,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: You are so merciful: I see your end;

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: 'Tis my undoing: love and meekness, lord,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Become a churchman better than ambition:

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Win straying souls with modesty again,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Cast none away. That I shall clear myself,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Lay all the weight ye can upon my patience,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: I make as little doubt, as you do conscience

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: In doing daily wrongs. I could say more,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: But reverence to your calling makes me modest.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: My lord, my lord, you are a sectary,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: That's the plain truth: your painted gloss discovers,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: To men that understand you, words and weakness.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: My Lord of Winchester, you are a little,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: By your good favour, too sharp; men so noble,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: However faulty, yet should find respect

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: For what they have been: 'tis a cruelty

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: To load a falling man.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Good master secretary,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: I cry your honour mercy; you may, worst

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Of all this table, say so.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Why, my lord?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Do not I know you for a favourer

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Of this new sect? ye are not sound.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Not sound?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Not sound, I say.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Would you were half so honest!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Men's prayers then would seek you, not their fears.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: I shall remember this bold language.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Do.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Remember your bold life too.

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: This is too much;

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Forbear, for shame, my lords.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: I have done.

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: And I.

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Then thus for you, my lord: it stands agreed,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: I take it, by all voices, that forthwith

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: You be convey'd to the Tower a prisoner;

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: There to remain till the king's further pleasure

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Be known unto us: are you all agreed, lords?

speaker: All
text_entry: We are.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Is there no other way of mercy,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: But I must needs to the Tower, my lords?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: What other

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Would you expect? you are strangely troublesome.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Let some o' the guard be ready there.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Enter Guard

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: For me?

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Must I go like a traitor thither?

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Receive him,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: And see him safe i' the Tower.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Stay, good my lords,

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: I have a little yet to say. Look there, my lords;

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: By virtue of that ring, I take my cause

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Out of the gripes of cruel men, and give it

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: To a most noble judge, the king my master.

speaker: Chamberlain
text_entry: This is the king's ring.

speaker: SURREY
text_entry: 'Tis no counterfeit.

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: 'Tis the right ring, by heaven: I told ye all,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: When ye first put this dangerous stone a-rolling,

speaker: SUFFOLK
text_entry: 'Twould fall upon ourselves.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Do you think, my lords,

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: The king will suffer but the little finger

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Of this man to be vex'd?

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: 'Tis now too certain:

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: How much more is his life in value with him?

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Would I were fairly out on't!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: My mind gave me,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: In seeking tales and informations

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Against this man, whose honesty the devil

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: And his disciples only envy at,

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Ye blew the fire that burns ye: now have at ye!

speaker: CROMWELL
text_entry: Enter KING, frowning on them; takes his seat

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Dread sovereign, how much are we bound to heaven

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: In daily thanks, that gave us such a prince;

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: Not only good and wise, but most religious:

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: One that, in all obedience, makes the church

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: The chief aim of his honour; and, to strengthen

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: That holy duty, out of dear respect,

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: His royal self in judgment comes to hear

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: The cause betwixt her and this great offender.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: You were ever good at sudden commendations,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Bishop of Winchester. But know, I come not

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To hear such flattery now, and in my presence;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: They are too thin and bare to hide offences.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To me you cannot reach, you play the spaniel,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And think with wagging of your tongue to win me;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: But, whatsoe'er thou takest me for, I'm sure

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Thou hast a cruel nature and a bloody.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To CRANMER

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Good man, sit down. Now let me see the proudest

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: He, that dares most, but wag his finger at thee:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: By all that's holy, he had better starve

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Than but once think this place becomes thee not.

speaker: SURREY
text_entry: May it please your grace,--

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: No, sir, it does not please me.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I had thought I had had men of some understanding

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: And wisdom of my council; but I find none.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Was it discretion, lords, to let this man,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: This good man,--few of you deserve that title,--

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: This honest man, wait like a lousy footboy

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: At chamber--door? and one as great as you are?

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Why, what a shame was this! Did my commission

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Bid ye so far forget yourselves? I gave ye

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Power as he was a counsellor to try him,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Not as a groom: there's some of ye, I see,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: More out of malice than integrity,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Would try him to the utmost, had ye mean;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Which ye shall never have while I live.

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Thus far,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: My most dread sovereign, may it like your grace

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: To let my tongue excuse all. What was purposed

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: Concerning his imprisonment, was rather,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: If there be faith in men, meant for his trial,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: And fair purgation to the world, than malice,

speaker: Chancellor
text_entry: I'm sure, in me.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Well, well, my lords, respect him;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Take him, and use him well, he's worthy of it.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I will say thus much for him, if a prince

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: May be beholding to a subject, I

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Am, for his love and service, so to him.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Make me no more ado, but all embrace him:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Be friends, for shame, my lords! My Lord of

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Canterbury,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: I have a suit which you must not deny me;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: That is, a fair young maid that yet wants baptism,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: You must be godfather, and answer for her.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: The greatest monarch now alive may glory

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: In such an honour: how may I deserve it

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: That am a poor and humble subject to you?

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Come, come, my lord, you'ld spare your spoons: you

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: shall have two noble partners with you; the old

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Duchess of Norfolk, and Lady Marquess Dorset: will

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: these please you?

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Once more, my Lord of Winchester, I charge you,

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Embrace and love this man.

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: With a true heart

speaker: GARDINER
text_entry: And brother-love I do it.

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: And let heaven

speaker: CRANMER
text_entry: Witness, how dear I hold this confirmation.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Good man, those joyful tears show thy true heart:

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: The common voice, I see, is verified

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Of thee, which says thus, 'Do my Lord of Canterbury

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: A shrewd turn, and he is your friend for ever.'

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Come, lords, we trifle time away; I long

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: To have this young one made a Christian.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: As I have made ye one, lords, one remain;

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: So I grow stronger, you more honour gain.

speaker: KING HENRY VIII
text_entry: Exeunt
